facts.text: Petitioners acquired over six acres of land by purchase for Rs. 4,50,009 in February 1961 under five sale deeds and one lease deed.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners who have acquired over six acres of land by purchase for Rs. 4,50,009 in February, 1961, under five sale deeds and one lease deed claim to have done so for the purpose of establishing a paper mill in companylaboration with Messrs. R. S. Madhoram and Sons who had been granted a licence for the establishment of a paper plant in Ghaziabad in Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Land is situated in village Meola Maharajpur, Tehsil Ballabhgarh, District Gurgaon, abuts on Mathura Road, 10-12 miles from New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid land is situate in the village Meola Maharajpur, Tehsil Ballabhgarh, District Gurgaon, and abuts on the Mathura Road, and is only about 10 or 12 miles from New Delhi.

facts.text: Respondent No. 6, Air Conditioning Corporation P Ltd., holds licence from Government of India for factory manufacturing refrigeration compressors and ancillary equipment.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 6, Air Conditioning Corporation P Ltd., is a private limited companycern and holds a licence from the Government of India for starting a factory for the manufacture of various ranges of refrigeration companypressors and ancillary equipment.

facts.text: Project initially allotted to West Bengal, shifted to Punjab at request of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: We may mention here that initially this project was allotted to the State of West Bengal but at the request of State of Punjab its location was shifted to the State of Punjab.

facts.text: Respondent No. 6 approached State of Punjab in March 1961 for acquiring land under Land Acquisition Act 1894 for factory.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners companytend that respondent No. 6 being interested in acquiring land in the village Meola Maharajpur approached the State of Punjab in or about the month of March, 1961, for the purpose of acquiring land for their factory under the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: One petitioner applied to Deputy Commissioner Gurgaon on March 23, 1961, requesting acquisition of their lands for benefit of Respondent No. 6.

anchor.surface_text: One of the petitioners having learnt of this made an application on March 23, 1961, to the Deputy Commissioner, Gurgaon, requesting him that numbere of the lands purchased by the petitioners should be acquired for the benefit, of respondent No. 6.

facts.text: Petitioners assured by Deputy Commissioner that their lands would be acquired for Respondent No. 6.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners allege that they were assured by the Deputy Commissioner that their lands would number be acquired for the benefit of respondent No. 6.

facts.text: Respondent No. 6 purchased contiguous plot of approx 70,000 sq yards on or about April 21, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter respondent No. 6 purchased by private treaty a, plot of land measuring approximately 70,000 sq. yards companytiguous to, the land owned by the petitioners on or about April 21, 1961.

facts.text: Governor of Punjab issued notification dated August 25, 1961 under s.4 of Land Acquisition Act declaring petitioners' lands likely needed for public purpose: setting up factory for refrigeration compressors.

anchor.surface_text: the Governor of Punjab, by numberification dated August 25, 1961, under s. 4 of the Act declared that the lands of the petitioners in this petition as well as those of the petitioners in the other two writ petitions were likely to be needed by Government at public , expense for a public purpose, namely, for setting up a factory for manufacturing various ranges of refrigeration companypressors.,and, ancillary equipment.

facts.text: Notification under s.4 authorized urgency under s.17, no s.5A inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: It further directed that action under s. 17 of the Act shall be taken because there was urgency and also directed that the provisions of s 5A shall number apply to the acquisition.

facts.text: Governor of Punjab made notification under s.6 dated August 19, 1961, satisfied land needed for public purpose, published August 25, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On August 19, the Governor of Punjab made a numberification under s. 6 of the Act to the effect that he was satisfied that the land specified in the numberification was required by Government at public expense for public purpose, namely, for setting up a factory for the manufacture of refrigeration companypressors and other ancillary equipment and declared that the aforesaid land was required for the aforesaid purposes.

facts.text: Petitioners purchased land bona fide for industrial purposes: paper mill, in collaboration with R.S. Madho Ram & Sons holding licence L/2-1/2 N-60/62.

anchor.surface_text: It is their companytention that they have purchased this land bona fide for industrial purposes as land in the vicinity of this land is being acquired by industrialists for establishing various industries. The purpose is said to be the establishment of a paper manufacturing plant. According to them they have entered into an arrangement with Messrs. R. S. Madho Ram Sons who hold industrial licence No. L/2-1/2 N-60/62.

facts.text: Proposed paper mill would employ about 200 people.

anchor.surface_text: The proposed industry, according to them, would employ about 200 people.

facts.text: Respondent No. 6 already engaged in refrigeration industry, factory at Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: whereas according to them, the respondent No. 6 is already engaged in refrigeration industry and as far as they know, it has established a factory for manufacturing refrigeration equipment at Hyderabad in the State of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: Government of Punjab sanctioned Rs. 100 expense for acquisition on September 29, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that some time after the numberification was published, that is, on September 29, 1961, the Government of Punjab sanctioned the expense of Rs. 100 for the purpose of acquisition of this land.

facts.text: Respondent No.1 denies petitioners purchased land for bona fide industrial purpose.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent No. 1 denied that the petitioners had purchased the land for a bona fide industrial purpose and would in fact use it for such purpose.

facts.text: Respondent No.1 admits Respondent No.6 applied in December 1960 for land acquisition.

anchor.surface_text: It also denied that any assurance was give to the petitioners that their lands would number be acquired. It admitted that the respondent No. 6 had made an application in December, 1960 for acquiring land for setting up its factory and that, therefore, the Punjab Government agreed to do the needful.

facts.text: State Government to make part contribution towards compensation from public revenues.

anchor.surface_text: According to respondent No. 1 the acquisition proceedings have been undertaken for a public purpose and at public expense as stated in the numberification and that the State Government would make part companytribution towards the, payment of companypensation of the land out of public revenues.

facts.text: Land purchased by Respondent No.6 has no access to main road and inadequate for requirements.

anchor.surface_text: It also stated that as the land purchased by the respondent No. 6 through private negotiation has numberaccess to the main road and as the land is inadequate to meet the minimum essential requirements the acquisition of the, lands in question became necessary.

facts.text: Licence to Messrs. R.S. Madho Ram & Sons granted August 17, 1960 for Ghaziabad UP, cancelled January 31, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In that affidavit it is denied that any licence had been granted to Messrs. R. S. Madho Ram Sons for the establishment of a paper plant in the Punjab. According to respondent No. 1 Messrs. R. S. Madho Ram Sons were granted a licence on August 17, 1960, for the establishment of an industrial undertaking in Ghaziabad U.P. for the manufacture of writing and printing paper and pulp. It further stated that even this licence has been cancelled by the Government of India by their letter dated January 31, 1962.

facts.text: Air Conditioning Corporation converted to public ltd company York India Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: It then stated that the Air Conditioning Corporation which was incorporated as a private limited companypany has since, with the permission of the Central Government, been companyverted into a public limited companypany with the name and style of York India Ltd.,

holdings.text: The declaration made by the Government under s.6(3) of the Land Acquisition Act is conclusive evidence that the land is needed for a public purpose or for a company.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 3 of s. 6 goes further and says that such a declaration shall be conclusive evidence that the land is needed for a public purpose or for a company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets s.6(3) using Evidence Act ss.3-4; no distinction between conclusive proof and evidence; shuts out other evidence; textual reading of LAA scheme.

holdings.text: Courts cannot inquire into whether acquisition is for public purpose absent colourable exercise of power or fraud.

anchor.surface_text: if there is a colourable exercise of power the declaration will be open to challenge at the instance of the aggrieved party.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exception to s.6(3) conclusiveness only for fraud on power; declaration final otherwise; follows precedents like Wijeyesekera.

holdings.text: Land Acquisition Act, being pre-Constitution law, protected by Art.31(5)(a); acquisition does not infringe Art.19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: pre-Constitution law is protected from the operation of Art. 31 2  by the provisions of Art. 31 5   a

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedents (Babu Barkya Thakur, Bhanji Munji); no right under Art.19(1)(f) if possession taken under protected law.

holdings.text: Acquisition is for public purpose partly at public expense, not for a company; Part VII inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: provisions of Part VII of the Act are inapplicable

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6 declaration specifies public purpose; Part VII only for company amenities/public utility under s.40; distinguishes R.L. Arora.

holdings.text: Rs.100 token contribution by State sufficient for 'partly at public expense'; not colourable exercise.

anchor.surface_text: the contribution of the Government towards the cost of acquisition being a very small fraction ... we are satisfied that it satisfies the requirement of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory requirement for substantial amount; follows Senja Naicken overruling Ponnaia; stare decisis and policy considerations.

holdings.text: Notifications under ss.4 and 6 valid despite publication on same day (s.6 dated Aug 19, s.4 Aug 25).

anchor.surface_text: On August 19, the Governor of Punjab made a notification under s. 6 of the Act to the effect that he was satisfied that the land specified in the notification

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.17(4) permits s.6 after s.4 publication; dates different, valid procedure.

holdings.text: No violation of Art.14; State may prefer one industry over another.

anchor.surface_text: No question of depriving them of their fundamental rights under Art. 19 1 f and g or of violation of their right under Art. 14 therefore arises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioners lack valid licence for Punjab (cancelled); rational preference for licensed industry; no equals.

holdings.text: Acquisition for setting up refrigeration compressors factory is for public purpose.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Beneficial to community (forex savings, employment, public utility); s.6(3) conclusive; facts undisputed (licence, collaboration).

holdings.text: Petitioners did not purchase land for bona fide industrial purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows licence for UP Ghaziabad, cancelled for no steps; rejects petitioner claim.

precedents.citation: State of Bihar Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameswarsingh of Darbhanga 1

anchor.surface_text: State of Bihar Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameswarsingh of Darbhanga 1 . There, Mahajan, J. as he then was,  has expressed the view that the exercise of power to acquire compulsorily is conditional on the existence of public purpose and that being so this condition is not an express provision of Art. 31 (2) but exists aliunde in the content of the power itself.

precedents.case_name: State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameswar Singh of Darbhanga
precedents.cited_proposition: Condition of public purpose for acquisition under Art 31(2)
precedents.cited_holding: Views differed among judges on whether public purpose is express or implied condition

precedents.citation: Babu Barkya Thakur v. The State of Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the law was challenged before this Court in Babu Barkya Thakur v. The State of Bombay 1  on the ground that it infringes the provisions of Arts. 31 (2) and 19 (1) (f) of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Babu Barkya Thakur v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Land Acquisition Act protected under Art 31(5)(a)
precedents.cited_holding: Pre-Constitution law protected from Art 31(2) challenge

precedents.citation: State of Bombay v. Bhanji Munji 2

anchor.surface_text: It also held, following the decision in the State of ,Bombay v. Bhanji Munji 2  and that in Lilavati Bai v. The State of Bombay 3  that the attack under Art. 19 (1) (f) of the Constitution is futile.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. Bhanji Munji
precedents.cited_proposition: Art 19(1)(f) not attracted if property taken under protected law
precedents.cited_holding: Right under Art 19(1)(f) requires possession not taken away by protected law

precedents.citation: Lilavati Bai v. The State of Bombay 3

anchor.surface_text: and that in Lilavati Bai v. The State of Bombay 3  that the attack under Art. 19 (1) (f) of the Constitution is futile. The argument, however, is that the protection which the Act enjoys is only to this extent that even though any of its provisions be in conflict with Art.31 (2) the Act cannot be challenged on that ground

precedents.case_name: Lilavati Bai v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Attack under Art 19(1)(f) futile for protected laws

precedents.citation: R. L. Arora v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1
